items.title: Ctrl-s and Ctrl-q don't work
items.body: These two keys correspond to "Pause transmission" and "Resume transmission" (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Software_flow_control). Ctrl-s has the effect of completely freezing the input until Ctrl-q is pressed. Is there any way to stop this and actually receive these key presses into the program?

items.title: Ctrl-DELETE is not recognised
items.body:
I am running a loop as shown in the examples:
```
with Input() as keys:
    for key in keys:
        print(key)
```
DELETE is recognised as expected but Ctrl-DELETE is not printed until the next character when it is shown as `^[[3;5~`. 

Adding the tuple `(b"\x1b[3;5~", u'<Ctrl-DELETE>')` to curtsieskeys.py fixes the problem for me but I'm not sure whether it'd cause problems elsewhere.

Let me know if there's a better way of handling this.
Thanks

items.title: Could you support standard ANSI intensity format?
items.body: According to https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ANSI_escape_code, one can add `;1` to display bright/bold text. But this currently doesn't work in bpython, instead, I have to prefix colored text with `\033[1m` to get bold effect. The inconsistency with standard ANSI escape code brings trouble to code that relies on it. Taking my current work [pdir2](https://github.com/laike9m/pdir2) as an example, [color](https://github.com/laike9m/pdir2/blob/master/pdir/constants.py#L189) can't be properly displayed in bpython. I would like to know if you have plan to support this? I understand that it may conflicts with the current design/API, and it's totally ok if you don't.

items.title: Documentation references removed module curtsies.terminal
items.body:
[Input.rst](https://github.com/thomasballinger/curtsies/blob/master/docs/Input.rst#input---events) says:

> To see what a given keypress is called (what unicode string is returned by Terminal.next()), try python -m curtsies.terminal and play around.

The problem is that `curtsies.terminal` was removed in 039832c9a99c415b9c8c91ba7274cca3c3416a28. I guess the mentioned command can be replaced with either `python -m curtsies.input` or `python -m curtsies.events`.

items.title: Fix arrow keys for some setups
items.body:
`\x1bOA` through D should be arrow keys, not ctrl-arrow. See https://github.com/bpython/bpython/issues/621

```
b'\x1bOA'
<Ctrl-UP>

---
b'\x1bOB'
<Ctrl-DOWN>

---
b'\x1bOD'
<Ctrl-LEFT>

---
b'\x1bOC'
<Ctrl-RIGHT>
```

items.title: Context needed

> "Curtsies is a library for interacting with the terminal."

Should become something like ...

> "Curtsies is a Python 2.x & 3.x compatible library for interacting with the terminal."

Cheers,
Trevor Sullivan
Microsoft MVP: PowerShell

items.title: curtsies.formatstring.FmtStr.ljust loses colors
items.body:
While looking at https://github.com/bpython/bpython/issues/439 I noticed that using `line.ljust` is not possible, since all color information is lost in the process. For example:

``` python
>>> t = fmtstr(u'asdf', 'blue', 'on_red', 'bold')
>>> x = fmtstr(u'asdf', 'green', 'on_red', 'bold')
>>> s = t + x
>>> s.ljust(10)
on_red(bold('asdfasdf  '))
```

items.title: FSArray needs width-aware compositing methods
Less magic
items.body: Python magic methods should reference normal methods with descriptive names - see `__getitem__` and `__setitem__` on FmtStr and FSArray.

items.title: FmtStrs should be double-width and zero-space character aware
items.body:
Since fmtstrs are used for layout in the terminal, their indexing math should be width-aware. This probably means:
- the width of a line is determined by analysizing its contents, not simply taking the length of the underlying unicode string
- ending with a zero-length character is not allowed
- indexing errors if a double width character gets chopped in half?

This is exciting, FmtStrs are about to get more useful (and we're about to have a lot more tests ;)

items.title: Real Documenation
items.body: Curtsies needs real documentation - not just a readme. A prose-style "build a X with curtsies" blog article would be good, as would docs on how to do the kind of repl interface that makes bpython-curtsies special. Jesse Jiryu Davis is visiting Hacker School on Monday to talk about technical writing - I'm going to tackle this after hopefully being inspired then.
